creditline: The Carl and Holly Jones Endowment for Prints and Drawings
description: black and white image; center figure with exposed muscular torso, draped in fabric, holding a staff with cross at end, PR hand raised, and halo around head; figure is encased in and oval shape that is surrounded by clouds and angels; open tomb in bottom center, surrounded by figures lying on the ground
provenance: Sale, Karl & Faber, Munich, November 1959; (C.G. Boerner, Neue Lagerliste 31, Düsseldorf 1961, no. 3 (stock no. 4207)); private collection, Germany; sale Arnold, Frankfurt, November 17, 2018, lot 652; (Helmut Rumbler, Frankfurt, 2018-19); (C.G. Boerner, New York, 2019-20).
text:
It is dawn. Angels have pulled aside the sarcophagus lid, and now—framed by clouds and a heavenly aureole—Christ hovers above his empty tomb. Soldiers in fanciful armor surround the tomb: some sleeping, some just roused, and others actively attempting to understand the miracle before them.

Albrecht Altdorfer was one of the foremost artists of Renaissance Germany. With the collaboration of a woodblock cutter whose name we do not know, he made this image with lines so fine that they rival the art of copper plate engraving. Note how the figure of Christ is printed more darkly than the rest of the image, thereby giving him added presence.
title: The Resurrection of Christ
